instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2179: What is A2179? A2179 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2020 with EMC 3302, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01958..
definitions.820-01958: What is 820-01958? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.A1932: What is A1932? A1932 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Late 2018, 2019 with EMC 3184, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01521..
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.

threads.title: MacBook Air 2020 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Water damage - clicking sound in the CPU area
threads.message:
Good evening,
I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with water damage. Corrosion was especially present around <TRANSISTOR>Q7680</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7660</TRANSISTOR>. There was also corrosion around CC714 / CC715, CC716, CC717, CC7A0, CC8A1, <RESISTOR>R7686</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7666</RESISTOR>, CC760, CC761, CC786, CC787, <CAPACITOR>C7681</CAPACITOR>, CC789, CC788, <CAPACITOR>C7660</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7060</CAPACITOR>, CC784, CC785, <RESISTOR>R7070</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7071</RESISTOR>, <DIODE>D7070</DIODE>, CC796, <TRANSISTOR>Q7070</TRANSISTOR>, but not as bad as between <TRANSISTOR>Q7680</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7660</TRANSISTOR>.

I'm not familiar with the MacBook Air yet; and I'm even less familiar with the after 2015 boards. That's the first one I see. I did read the [URL]https://repair.wiki/w/A2179_2020_MacBook_Air[/URL], and the below thread:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-a-model-<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>-water-damage.63359/[/URL]

[ATTACH]61119[/ATTACH][ATTACH]61121[/ATTACH]

Measurements taken in the corroded areas, which I've cleaned:
<RESISTOR>R7686</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7666</RESISTOR> reads 1.5 Ohms, seems okish.
<RESISTOR>R7070</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7071</RESISTOR> are okish too.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: stable at 12.57V
<TRANSISTOR>Q7660</TRANSISTOR>: 12.57V on pin 2, 5.11V on pin 3 and 4, 41.9mV on pin 5, 5.08V on pin 6,7,8
<TRANSISTOR>Q7680</TRANSISTOR>: 12.58V on pin 2, 3.33V on pin 3 and 4, 3.3V pin 6, 7, 8, pin 5 83mV
L7400: 1.8V, diode mode obviously does not beep and resistance is around 187 Ohms.
L7230, L7220, L7210: 6.2mV

I ordered a USB-C ampmeter, I'm clueless regarding how much mAh/Volts it takes.

The MacBook does not boot, there is no chime, there is no sign of life and the fan does not spin. The CPU area gets warm, though.

The sound starts to be audible ~10 sec after I press on "On".

The other side of the board was perfectly clean, no corrosion.

The customer said the water came from the back of the MacBook AIr. Someone spilled a glass of water behind it.

Since the T2 chip is present on this model, I guess that if the macbook is unable to boot, data are lost? Data encryption keys being in the T2...would it be doable to unsolder both the T2 chip and the SSDs? Then what? Solder them back in another macbook ? Doesn't seem to be worth the troubles

threads.title: MacBook Air 2020 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Water damage - clicking sound in the CPU area
threads.message:
Check <RESISTOR>R7665</RESISTOR>/85.
Replace <CAPACITOR>C7669</CAPACITOR>/89.

Do you get voltage at L7700 and L8100/50?

<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (similar to <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1932</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>) suffers a lot because of audio board corrosion.
Remove and inspect it, as audio flex too.

threads.title: MacBook Air 2020 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Water damage - clicking sound in the CPU area
threads.message:
Good evening 2informaticos, thanks for your help!
I do have voltage on L7700, pin 1: 1.81V
I do have votage on L8100, pin 1: 1.09V, both side
On L8150, pin1: 2.64V, pin2: 0.606V, but, most of the time, it is 1.1V on both side. I would have expected 0.6V considering the boardview but I read 0.606 V only once.

On <RESISTOR>R7665</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7685</RESISTOR> I read 0.5 Ohm
Regarding <CAPACITOR>C7669</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7689</CAPACITOR>, sorry sir but my multimeter shows 100 nF on both, which is in line with the schematics showing 0.1uF.
Unless the schematics must be considered as wrong, perhaps it is better to keep these 2caps in place.

threads.title: MacBook Air 2020 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Water damage - clicking sound in the CPU area
threads.message:
I mentioned these resistors and caps to check, because of advanced corrosion.
Is better to have new/clean components in boost circuits.
If any fail soon, <TRANSISTOR>Q7660</TRANSISTOR>/80 wil burn.

Check <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and all surrounding components.
Be sure it gets power (41/42) and enable (48).
If all good there, CPU is probably dead.

threads.title: MacBook Air 2020 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Water damage - clicking sound in the CPU area
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, 
Pin 41: 12.55V, 
pin 42: 5.1V
pin 48: 0.81V

Is it normal to have <SIGNAL>PPV1V05_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>  to 0.988V?

threads.title: MacBook Air 2020 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Water damage - clicking sound in the CPU area
MacBook Air 2020 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2179</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - Water damage - clicking sound in the CPU area
threads.message:
R.I.P then :(
CPU dead, data lost....

Thanks for your assistance, 2informaticos
